segment.source: description: This topic presents a case study of porting a very simple Universal 8.1 app to a Windows 10&\#160;Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.
segment.target: description: This topic presents a case study of porting a very simple Universal 8.1 app to a Windows 10&\#160;Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.

segment.source: title: Windows Runtime 8.x to UWP case study: Bookstore1
segment.target: title: Windows Runtime 8.x to UWP case study: Bookstore1

segment.source: Windows Runtime 8.x to UWP case study: Bookstore1
segment.target: Windows Runtime 8.x to UWP case study: Bookstore1

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: This topic presents a case study of porting a very simple Universal 8.1 app to a Windows 10 Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.
segment.target: This topic presents a case study of porting a very simple Universal 8.1 app to a Windows 10 Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.

segment.source: A Universal 8.1 app is one that builds one app package for Windows 8.1, and a different app package for Windows Phone 8.1.
segment.target: A Universal 8.1 app is one that builds one app package for Windows 8.1, and a different app package for Windows Phone 8.1.

segment.source: With Windows 10, you can create a single app package that your customers can install onto a wide range of devices, and that's what we'll do in this case study.
segment.target: With Windows 10, you can create a single app package that your customers can install onto a wide range of devices, and that's what we'll do in this case study.

segment.source: See Guide to UWP apps.
segment.target: See Guide to UWP apps.

segment.source: The app we'll port consists of a ListBox bound to a view model.
segment.target: The app we'll port consists of a ListBox bound to a view model.

segment.source: The view model has a list of books that shows title, author, and book cover.
segment.target: The view model has a list of books that shows title, author, and book cover.

segment.source: The book cover images have Build Action set to Content and Copy to Output Directory set to Do not copy.
segment.target: The book cover images have Build Action set to Content and Copy to Output Directory set to Do not copy.

segment.source: The previous topics in this section describe the differences between the platforms, and they give details and guidance on the porting process for various aspects of an app from XAML markup, through binding to a view model, down to accessing data.
segment.target: The previous topics in this section describe the differences between the platforms, and they give details and guidance on the porting process for various aspects of an app from XAML markup, through binding to a view model, down to accessing data.

segment.source: A case study aims to complement that guidance by showing it in action in a real example.
segment.target: A case study aims to complement that guidance by showing it in action in a real example.

segment.source: The case studies assume you've read the guidance, which they do not repeat.
segment.target: The case studies assume you've read the guidance, which they do not repeat.

segment.source: Note When opening Bookstore1Universal\_10 in Visual Studio, if you see the message "Visual Studio update required", then follow the steps in TargetPlatformVersion.
segment.target: Note When opening Bookstore1Universal\_10 in Visual Studio, if you see the message "Visual Studio update required", then follow the steps in TargetPlatformVersion.

segment.source: Downloads
segment.target: Downloads

segment.source: Download the Bookstore1\_81 Universal 8.1 app.
segment.target: Download the Bookstore1\_81 Universal 8.1 app.

segment.source: Download the Bookstore1Universal\_10 Windows 10 app.
segment.target: Download the Bookstore1Universal\_10 Windows 10 app.

segment.source: The Universal 8.1 app
segment.target: The Universal 8.1 app

segment.source: Here’s what Bookstore1\_81—the app that we're going to port—looks like.
segment.target: Here’s what Bookstore1\_81—the app that we're going to port—looks like.

segment.source: It's just a vertically-scrolling list box of books beneath the heading of the app's name and page title.
segment.target: It's just a vertically-scrolling list box of books beneath the heading of the app's name and page title.

segment.source: how bookstore1\-81 looks on windows
segment.target: how bookstore1\-81 looks on windows

segment.source: Bookstore1\_81 on Windows
segment.target: Bookstore1\_81 on Windows

segment.source: how bookstore1\-81 looks on windows phone
segment.target: how bookstore1\-81 looks on windows phone

segment.source: Bookstore1\_81 on Windows Phone
segment.target: Bookstore1\_81 on Windows Phone

segment.source: Porting to a Windows 10 project
segment.target: Porting to a Windows 10 project

segment.source: The Bookstore1\_81 solution is an 8.1 Universal App project, and it contains these projects.
segment.target: The Bookstore1\_81 solution is an 8.1 Universal App project, and it contains these projects.

segment.source: Bookstore1\_81.Windows.
segment.target: Bookstore1\_81.Windows.

segment.source: This is the project that builds the app package for Windows 8.1.
segment.target: This is the project that builds the app package for Windows 8.1.

segment.source: Bookstore1\_81.WindowsPhone.
segment.target: Bookstore1\_81.WindowsPhone.

segment.source: This is the project that builds the app package for Windows Phone 8.1.
segment.target: This is the project that builds the app package for Windows Phone 8.1.

segment.source: Bookstore1\_81.Shared.
segment.target: Bookstore1\_81.Shared.

segment.source: This is the project that contains source code, markup files, and other assets and resources, that are used by both of the other two projects.
segment.target: This is the project that contains source code, markup files, and other assets and resources, that are used by both of the other two projects.

segment.source: For this case study, we have the usual options described in If you have a Universal 8.1 app with respect to what devices to support.
segment.target: For this case study, we have the usual options described in If you have a Universal 8.1 app with respect to what devices to support.

segment.source: The decision here is a simple one: this app has the same features, and does so mostly with the same code, in both its Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1 forms.
segment.target: The decision here is a simple one: this app has the same features, and does so mostly with the same code, in both its Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1 forms.

segment.source: So, we'll port the contents of the Shared project (and anything else we need from the other projects) to a Windows 10 that targets the Universal device family (one that you can install onto the widest range of devices).
segment.target: So, we'll port the contents of the Shared project (and anything else we need from the other projects) to a Windows 10 that targets the Universal device family (one that you can install onto the widest range of devices).

segment.source: It's a very quick task to create a new project in Visual Studio, copy files over to it from Bookstore1\_81, and include the copied files in the new project.
segment.target: It's a very quick task to create a new project in Visual Studio, copy files over to it from Bookstore1\_81, and include the copied files in the new project.

segment.source: Start by creating a new Blank Application (Windows Universal) project.
segment.target: Start by creating a new Blank Application (Windows Universal) project.

segment.source: Name it Bookstore1Universal\_10.
segment.target: Name it Bookstore1Universal\_10.

segment.source: These are the files to copy over from Bookstore1\_81 to Bookstore1Universal\_10.
segment.target: These are the files to copy over from Bookstore1\_81 to Bookstore1Universal\_10.

segment.source: From the Shared project
segment.target: From the Shared project

segment.source: Copy the folder containing the book cover image PNG files (the folder is \\Assets\\CoverImages).
segment.target: Copy the folder containing the book cover image PNG files (the folder is \\Assets\\CoverImages).

segment.source: After copying the folder, in Solution Explorer, make sure Show All Files is toggled on.
segment.target: After copying the folder, in Solution Explorer, make sure Show All Files is toggled on.

segment.source: Right-click the folder that you copied and click Include In Project.
segment.target: Right-click the folder that you copied and click Include In Project.

segment.source: That command is what we mean by "including" files or folders in a project.
segment.target: That command is what we mean by "including" files or folders in a project.

segment.source: Each time you copy a file or folder, each copy, click Refresh in Solution Explorer and then include the file or folder in the project.
segment.target: Each time you copy a file or folder, each copy, click Refresh in Solution Explorer and then include the file or folder in the project.

segment.source: There's no need to do this for files that you're replacing in the destination.
segment.target: There's no need to do this for files that you're replacing in the destination.

segment.source: Copy the folder containing the view model source file (the folder is \\ViewModel).
segment.target: Copy the folder containing the view model source file (the folder is \\ViewModel).

segment.source: Copy MainPage.xaml and replace the file in the destination.
segment.target: Copy MainPage.xaml and replace the file in the destination.

segment.source: From the Windows project
segment.target: From the Windows project

segment.source: Copy BookstoreStyles.xaml.
segment.target: Copy BookstoreStyles.xaml.

segment.source: We'll use this one as a good starting-point because all the resource keys in this file will resolve in a Windows 10 app; some of those in the equivalent WindowsPhone file will not.
segment.target: We'll use this one as a good starting-point because all the resource keys in this file will resolve in a Windows 10 app; some of those in the equivalent WindowsPhone file will not.

segment.source: Edit the source code and markup files that you just copied and change any references to the Bookstore1\_81 namespace to Bookstore1Universal\_10.
segment.target: Edit the source code and markup files that you just copied and change any references to the Bookstore1\_81 namespace to Bookstore1Universal\_10.

segment.source: A quick way to do that is to use the Replace In Files feature.
segment.target: A quick way to do that is to use the Replace In Files feature.

segment.source: No code changes are needed in the view model, nor in any other imperative code.
segment.target: No code changes are needed in the view model, nor in any other imperative code.

segment.source: But, just to make it easier to see which version of the app is running, change the value returned by the Bookstore1Universal\_10.BookstoreViewModel.AppName property from "BOOKSTORE1\_81" to "BOOKSTORE1UNIVERSAL\_10".
segment.target: But, just to make it easier to see which version of the app is running, change the value returned by the Bookstore1Universal\_10.BookstoreViewModel.AppName property from "BOOKSTORE1\_81" to "BOOKSTORE1UNIVERSAL\_10".

segment.source: Right now, you can build and run.
segment.target: Right now, you can build and run.

segment.source: Here's how our new UWP app looks after having done no explicit work yet to port it to Windows 10.
segment.target: Here's how our new UWP app looks after having done no explicit work yet to port it to Windows 10.

segment.source: the windows 10 app with initial source code changes
segment.target: the windows 10 app with initial source code changes

segment.source: The Windows 10 app with initial source code changes running on a Desktop device
segment.target: The Windows 10 app with initial source code changes running on a Desktop device

segment.source: the windows 10 app with initial source code changes
segment.target: the windows 10 app with initial source code changes

segment.source: The Windows 10 app with initial source code changes running on a Mobile device
segment.target: The Windows 10 app with initial source code changes running on a Mobile device

segment.source: The view and the view model are working together correctly, and the ListBox is functioning.
segment.target: The view and the view model are working together correctly, and the ListBox is functioning.

segment.source: We just need to fix the styling.
segment.target: We just need to fix the styling.

segment.source: On a Mobile device, in light theme, we can see the border of the list box, but that will be easy to hide.
segment.target: On a Mobile device, in light theme, we can see the border of the list box, but that will be easy to hide.

segment.source: And, the typography is too big, so we'll change the styles we're using.
segment.target: And, the typography is too big, so we'll change the styles we're using.

segment.source: Also, the app should be light in color when running on a Desktop device if we want it to look like the default.
segment.target: Also, the app should be light in color when running on a Desktop device if we want it to look like the default.

segment.source: So, we'll change that.
segment.target: So, we'll change that.

segment.source: Universal styling
segment.target: Universal styling

segment.source: The Bookstore1\_81 app used two different resource dictionaries (BookstoreStyles.xaml) to tailor its styles to the Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1 operating systems.
segment.target: The Bookstore1\_81 app used two different resource dictionaries (BookstoreStyles.xaml) to tailor its styles to the Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1 operating systems.

segment.source: Neither of those two BookstoreStyles.xaml files contains exactly the styles we need for our Windows 10 app.
segment.target: Neither of those two BookstoreStyles.xaml files contains exactly the styles we need for our Windows 10 app.

segment.source: But, the good news is that what we want is actually much simpler than either of them.
segment.target: But, the good news is that what we want is actually much simpler than either of them.

segment.source: So, the next steps will mostly involve removing and simplifying our project files and markup.
segment.target: So, the next steps will mostly involve removing and simplifying our project files and markup.

segment.source: The steps are below.
segment.target: The steps are below.

segment.source: And you can use the links at the top of this topic to download the projects and see the results of all the changes between here and the end of the case study.
segment.target: And you can use the links at the top of this topic to download the projects and see the results of all the changes between here and the end of the case study.

segment.source: To tighten up the spacing between items, find the data template in MainPage.xaml and delete the from the root Grid.
segment.target: To tighten up the spacing between items, find the data template in MainPage.xaml and delete the from the root Grid.

segment.source: Also, in , there are references to and .
segment.target: Also, in , there are references to and .

segment.source: Bookstore1\_81 used those keys as an indirection so that a single key had different implementations in the two apps.
segment.target: Bookstore1\_81 used those keys as an indirection so that a single key had different implementations in the two apps.

segment.source: We don't need that indirection any more; we can just reference system styles directly.
segment.target: We don't need that indirection any more; we can just reference system styles directly.

segment.source: So, replace those references with and , respectively.
segment.target: So, replace those references with and , respectively.

segment.source: Now, we need to set 's Background to the correct default value so that the app looks appropriate when running on all devices no matter what the theme is.
segment.target: Now, we need to set 's Background to the correct default value so that the app looks appropriate when running on all devices no matter what the theme is.

segment.source: Change it from to .
segment.target: Change it from to .

segment.source: In , change the reference to (which is now a little too big) to a reference to .
segment.target: In , change the reference to (which is now a little too big) to a reference to .

segment.source: is another Bookstore1\_81 indirection that we don't need any longer.
segment.target: is another Bookstore1\_81 indirection that we don't need any longer.

segment.source: Change that to reference instead.
segment.target: Change that to reference instead.

segment.source: We no longer need to set any special Background, Style, nor ItemContainerStyle on the ListBox, so just delete those three attributes and their values from the markup.
segment.target: We no longer need to set any special Background, Style, nor ItemContainerStyle on the ListBox, so just delete those three attributes and their values from the markup.

segment.source: We do want to hide the border of the ListBox, though, so add to it.
segment.target: We do want to hide the border of the ListBox, though, so add to it.

segment.source: We're not referencing any of the resources in the BookstoreStyles.xaml ResourceDictionary file any longer.
segment.target: We're not referencing any of the resources in the BookstoreStyles.xaml ResourceDictionary file any longer.

segment.source: You can delete all of those resources.
segment.target: You can delete all of those resources.

segment.source: But, don't delete the BookstoreStyles.xaml file itself: we still have one last use for it, as you'll see in the next section.
segment.target: But, don't delete the BookstoreStyles.xaml file itself: we still have one last use for it, as you'll see in the next section.

segment.source: That last sequence of styling operations leaves the app looking like this.
segment.target: That last sequence of styling operations leaves the app looking like this.

segment.source: the almost-ported windows 10 app
segment.target: the almost-ported windows 10 app

segment.source: The almost-ported Windows 10 app running on a Desktop device
segment.target: The almost-ported Windows 10 app running on a Desktop device

segment.source: the almost-ported windows 10 app
segment.target: the almost-ported windows 10 app

segment.source: The almost-ported Windows 10 app running on a Mobile device
segment.target: The almost-ported Windows 10 app running on a Mobile device

segment.source: An optional adjustment to the list box for Mobile devices
segment.target: An optional adjustment to the list box for Mobile devices

segment.source: When the app is running on a Mobile device, the background of a list box is light by default in both themes.
segment.target: When the app is running on a Mobile device, the background of a list box is light by default in both themes.

segment.source: That may be the style that you prefer and, if so, then there's nothing more to do except to tidy up: delete the BookstoreStyles.xaml resource dictionary file from your project, and remove the markup that merges it into MainPage.xaml.
segment.target: That may be the style that you prefer and, if so, then there's nothing more to do except to tidy up: delete the BookstoreStyles.xaml resource dictionary file from your project, and remove the markup that merges it into MainPage.xaml.

segment.source: But, controls are designed so that you can customize their look while leaving their behavior unaffected.
segment.target: But, controls are designed so that you can customize their look while leaving their behavior unaffected.

segment.source: So, if you want the list box to be dark in the dark theme—the way the original app looked—then this section describes a way to do that.
segment.target: So, if you want the list box to be dark in the dark theme—the way the original app looked—then this section describes a way to do that.

segment.source: The change we make only needs to affect the app when it's running on Mobile devices.
segment.target: The change we make only needs to affect the app when it's running on Mobile devices.

segment.source: So, we'll use a very slightly customized list box style when we're running on the Mobile device family, and we'll continue to use the default style when we're running everywhere else.
segment.target: So, we'll use a very slightly customized list box style when we're running on the Mobile device family, and we'll continue to use the default style when we're running everywhere else.

segment.source: To do that, we'll make a copy of BookstoreStyles.xaml and we'll give it a special MRT-qualified name, which will cause it to be loaded only on Mobile devices.
segment.target: To do that, we'll make a copy of BookstoreStyles.xaml and we'll give it a special MRT-qualified name, which will cause it to be loaded only on Mobile devices.

segment.source: Add a new ResourceDictionary project item and name it BookstoreStyles.DeviceFamily-Mobile.xaml.
segment.target: Add a new ResourceDictionary project item and name it BookstoreStyles.DeviceFamily-Mobile.xaml.

segment.source: You now have two files both of whose logical name is BookstoreStyles.xaml (and that's the name you use in your markup and code).
segment.target: You now have two files both of whose logical name is BookstoreStyles.xaml (and that's the name you use in your markup and code).

segment.source: The files have different physical names, though, so they can contain different markup.
segment.target: The files have different physical names, though, so they can contain different markup.

segment.source: You can use this MRT-qualified naming scheme with any xaml file, but be aware that all xaml files with the same logical name share a single xaml.cs code-behind file (where one is applicable).
segment.target: You can use this MRT-qualified naming scheme with any xaml file, but be aware that all xaml files with the same logical name share a single xaml.cs code-behind file (where one is applicable).

segment.source: Edit a copy of the control template for the list box and store that with the key of in the new resource dictionary, BookstoreStyles.DeviceFamily-Mobile.xaml.
segment.target: Edit a copy of the control template for the list box and store that with the key of in the new resource dictionary, BookstoreStyles.DeviceFamily-Mobile.xaml.

segment.source: Now, we'll make simple changes to three of the setters.
segment.target: Now, we'll make simple changes to three of the setters.

segment.source: In the Foreground setter, change the value to .
segment.target: In the Foreground setter, change the value to .

segment.source: Note that setting a property to directly on an element is the same as setting it to in code.
segment.target: Note that setting a property to directly on an element is the same as setting it to in code.

segment.source: But, using a value of in a setter has a unique effect: it overrides the setter in the default style (for the same property) and restores the default value of the property on the target element.
segment.target: But, using a value of in a setter has a unique effect: it overrides the setter in the default style (for the same property) and restores the default value of the property on the target element.

segment.source: In the Background setter, change the value to to remove that light background.
segment.target: In the Background setter, change the value to to remove that light background.

segment.source: In the Template setter, find the visual state named and delete its Storyboard, making it into an empty tag.
segment.target: In the Template setter, find the visual state named and delete its Storyboard, making it into an empty tag.

segment.source: Delete all the other setters from the markup.
segment.target: Delete all the other setters from the markup.

segment.source: Finally, copy into BookstoreStyles.xaml and delete its three setters, making it into an empty tag.
segment.target: Finally, copy into BookstoreStyles.xaml and delete its three setters, making it into an empty tag.

segment.source: We do this so that on devices other than Mobile ones, our reference to BookstoreStyles.xaml and to will resolve, but will have no effect.
segment.target: We do this so that on devices other than Mobile ones, our reference to BookstoreStyles.xaml and to will resolve, but will have no effect.

segment.source: the ported windows 10 app
segment.target: the ported windows 10 app

segment.source: The ported Windows 10 app running on a Mobile device
segment.target: The ported Windows 10 app running on a Mobile device

segment.source: Conclusion
segment.target: Conclusion

segment.source: This case study showed the process of porting a very simple app—arguably an unrealistically simple one.
segment.target: This case study showed the process of porting a very simple app—arguably an unrealistically simple one.

segment.source: For instance, a list box can be used for selection or for establishing a context for navigation; the app navigates to a page with more details about the item that was tapped.
segment.target: For instance, a list box can be used for selection or for establishing a context for navigation; the app navigates to a page with more details about the item that was tapped.

segment.source: This particular app does nothing with the user's selection, and it has no navigation.
segment.target: This particular app does nothing with the user's selection, and it has no navigation.

segment.source: Even so, the case study served to break the ice, to introduce the porting process, and to demonstrate important techniques that you can use in real UWP apps.
segment.target: Even so, the case study served to break the ice, to introduce the porting process, and to demonstrate important techniques that you can use in real UWP apps.

segment.source: We also saw evidence that porting view models is generally a smooth process.
segment.target: We also saw evidence that porting view models is generally a smooth process.

segment.source: User interface, and form factor support, are aspects that are more likely to require our attention when porting.
segment.target: User interface, and form factor support, are aspects that are more likely to require our attention when porting.

segment.source: The next case study is Bookstore2, in which we look at accessing and displaying grouped data.
segment.target: The next case study is Bookstore2, in which we look at accessing and displaying grouped data.
